1.text: Man, that is born of a woman, Is of few days, and full of trouble.

2.text: He cometh forth like a flower, and is cut down: He fleeth also as a shadow, and continueth not.

3.text: And dost thou open thine eyes upon such a one, And bringest me into judgment with thee?

4.text: Who can bring a clean thing out of an unclean? not one.

5.text: Seeing his days are determined, The number of his months is with thee, And thou hast appointed his bounds that he cannot pass;

6.text: Look away from him, that he may rest, Till he shall accomplish, as a hireling, his day.

7.text: For there is hope of a tree, If it be cut down, that it will sprout again, And that the tender branch thereof will not cease.

8.text: Though the root thereof wax old in the earth, And the stock thereof die in the ground;

9.text: Yet through the scent of water it will bud, And put forth boughs like a plant.

10.text: But man dieth, and is laid low: Yea, man giveth up the ghost, and where is he?

11.text: As the waters fail from the sea, And the river wasteth and drieth up;

12.text: So man lieth down and riseth not: Till the heavens be no more, they shall not awake, Nor be roused out of their sleep.

13.text: Oh that thou wouldest hide me in Sheol, That thou wouldest keep me secret, until thy wrath be past, That thou wouldest appoint me a set time, and remember me!

14.text: If a man die, shall he live again? All the days of my warfare would I wait, Till my release should come.

15.text: Thou wouldest call, and I would answer thee: Thou wouldest have a desire to the work of thy hands.

16.text: But now thou numberest my steps: Dost thou not watch over my sin?

17.text: My transgression is sealed up in a bag, And thou fastenest up mine iniquity.

18.text: But the mountain falling cometh to nought; And the rock is removed out of its place;

19.text: The waters wear the stones; The overflowings thereof wash away the dust of the earth: So thou destroyest the hope of man.

20.text: Thou prevailest for ever against him, and he passeth; Thou changest his countenance, and sendest him away.

21.text: His sons come to honor, and he knoweth it not; And they are brought low, but he perceiveth it not of them.

22.text: But his flesh upon him hath pain, And his soul within him mourneth.
